back: To successfully reach a goal or result.
example: Students who set clear objectives are more likely to achieve academic success.

back: To have an impact or influence on something.
example: Air pollution can adversely affect the health of urban populations.

back: To examine something in detail to understand it.

back: A method or way of dealing with something.

back: A particular part or feature of something.

back: To evaluate or judge the quality of something.

back: To accept something as true without proof.

back: A settled opinion or feeling about something.

back: Able to be used or obtained.

back: An advantage or positive outcome from something.

back: Something that produces an effect or result.

back: A difficult problem or task requiring effort.
example: Climate change represents one of the greatest challenges facing modern society.

back: A legally recognized member of a state.

back: To state something as true or demand as a right.

back: To arrange things into categories or groups.

back: A group of people sharing a location or interest.

back: To examine similarities and differences between things.
example: This essay will compare the effectiveness of public and private healthcare systems.

back: Made of many interconnected parts; difficult to understand.

back: An abstract idea or general principle.

back: A worry or issue that causes anxiety or interest.
example: Growing concern over plastic pollution has prompted many governments to act.

back: To reach a decision or judgment after reasoning.
example: The study concludes that regular exercise significantly reduces the risk of depression.

back: The state or circumstances affecting something.

back: To carry out an activity; behaviour or manner.

back: A result or effect of an action or event.

back: To think carefully about something before deciding.

back: To be made up or composed of parts.
example: A balanced diet should consist of proteins

back: To use up a resource or eat/drink something.

back: To give or add to a collective effort or outcome.

back: To regulate or have power over something.

back: To bring something into existence.
example: Investment in renewable energy can create thousands of new jobs across the economy.

back: To decrease or become smaller over time.

back: To state the meaning or nature of something.

back: The need or desire for a good or service.

back: To rely on someone or something for support.

back: To grow
example: progress

back: The process of increasing in size or value.

back: To make or become better in quality.

back: A single person

back: An absence or shortage of something needed.

back: Clearly visible or obvious; seeming to be true.

back: Subjects taught in a school or course.

back: To make an action or process easier.

back: Able to adapt to changing conditions easily.

back: Energy source formed from ancient organic matter.

back: Easily broken or damaged; delicate and vulnerable.

back: Forming an essential foundation or core.

back: A general rise in prices over time.
example: High inflation erodes purchasing power and disproportionately affects low-income households.

back: Introduction of new ideas
example: methods
column6: Continued innovation in renewable energy is essential to achieving global sustainability goals.

back: Reciprocal action or communication between parties.
example: Face-to-face interaction is vital for developing essential social skills in young children.

back: Action taken to improve or prevent a situation.
example: Early government intervention is essential to prevent the worsening of a financial crisis.

back: Allocating resources expecting future benefit.
example: Foreign direct investment plays a crucial role in accelerating economic growth in developing nations.

back: Laws or a body of laws enacted by government.
example: Stronger legislation is needed to protect workers from unsafe conditions in the workplace.

back: The ability to read
example: write
column6: High literacy rates are strongly associated with improved economic productivity and social outcomes.

back: To treat a group as unimportant or peripheral.
example: Economic policies that ignore rural areas tend to further marginalize already vulnerable communities.

back: A system or process for achieving a result.
example: Effective regulatory mechanisms are vital to prevent monopolistic practices in free markets.

back: A system of methods used in research.
example: The study's conclusions were questioned due to significant flaws in its research methodology.

back: Movement of people from one place to another.
example: Economic migration to urban centres has accelerated in many developing countries in recent decades.

back: An established set of attitudes or beliefs.
example: A growth mindset encourages students to view mistakes as opportunities for learning.

back: The ability to move freely between positions.
example: Education is widely regarded as the primary driver of social mobility in modern societies.

back: The rate of deaths in a population.
example: Improved sanitation has dramatically reduced child mortality rates in developing countries.

back: The reason or drive behind a person's action.
example: Students with high intrinsic motivation tend to outperform those driven only by external rewards.

back: Relating to a town or city government.
example: Municipal authorities are responsible for managing waste collection and public transportation systems.

back: A spoken or written account of events.
example: The media plays a powerful role in shaping the public narrative around immigration.

back: To reach agreement through discussion.
example: World leaders must negotiate binding agreements to effectively address global climate change.

back: The condition of being excessively overweight.
example: Childhood obesity rates have risen sharply in many countries due to unhealthy dietary habits.

back: A moral or legal duty to do something.
example: Wealthy nations have a moral obligation to assist countries most affected by climate change.

back: Something that blocks progress or achievement.
example: Lack of funding remains a significant obstacle to educational reform in many nations.

back: Resistance or conflict against something.
example: The proposed road expansion has met fierce opposition from local environmental groups.

back: Produced without artificial chemicals; naturally occurring.
example: The demand for organic food has grown significantly as consumers become more health-conscious.

back: Too many people in a limited space.
example: Rapid urbanisation has led to severe overcrowding in major cities across the developing world.

back: A disease spreading across entire countries worldwide.
example: The COVID-19 pandemic exposed critical weaknesses in global public health infrastructure.

back: A punishment for breaking a rule or law.
example: Introducing heavier financial penalties for pollution may deter industries from environmental violations.

back: A belief or interpretation of something.
example: Public perception of immigration is often shaped by media coverage rather than statistical evidence.

back: A particular viewpoint or way of seeing things.
example: It is essential to consider the issue from the perspective of those most directly affected.

back: An observable fact or event
example: often remarkable.
column5: Urbanisation is a global phenomenon that presents both opportunities and significant challenges.

back: The state of being extremely poor.
example: Eradicating extreme poverty remains one of the most important goals of international development.

back: An unfair opinion not based on reason.
example: Combating racial prejudice requires both legal reform and widespread educational initiatives.

back: Something ranked as most important.
example: Improving access to quality education should be the top priority of any responsible government.

back: The efficiency of output per unit of input.
example: Investing in employee training is one of the most effective ways to boost workplace productivity.

back: Favouring reform and social advancement.
example: A progressive tax system ensures that higher-income earners contribute a greater proportion.

back: A part of a whole; a comparative ratio.
example: A disproportionate share of national wealth is owned by a small proportion of the population.

back: Relating to the mind and mental processes.
example: Unemployment can have serious psychological consequences
column5: including depression and loss of identity.

back: A period of significant economic decline.
example: During a recession
column5: rising unemployment and reduced consumer spending create a negative cycle.

back: Process of restoring health or normal life.
example: Investing in rehabilitation programmes reduces reoffending rates more effectively than imprisonment alone.

back: A resource that can be naturally replenished.
example: Investment in renewable energy sources is vital to reduce dependence on fossil fuels globally.

back: A rule or condition that limits activity.
example: Travel restrictions imposed during the pandemic caused significant disruption to global tourism.

back: Income generated by a government or business.
example: Governments rely on tax revenue to fund essential public services such as healthcare and education.

back: A dramatic and fundamental change in society.
example: The industrial revolution fundamentally transformed the global economy and patterns of human labour.

back: Systems for maintaining hygiene and waste management.
example: Inadequate sanitation in densely populated urban areas contributes to the spread of infectious disease.

back: Insufficient supply of a needed resource.
example: Water scarcity poses one of the most serious threats to human survival in the coming decades.

back: Inclined to question or doubt claims.
example: Many economists remain skeptical about the long-term sustainability of current government spending.

back: Ability to move between social classes.
example: Education is widely considered the most powerful tool for improving social mobility.

back: A fixed oversimplified image of a group.
example: Media representations often reinforce harmful stereotypes about minority communities.

back: Something that provokes a response or activity.
example: The government launched a large stimulus package to revive the economy after the recession.

back: A residential area on the outskirts of a city.
example: The growth of suburbs has increased car dependency and contributed to urban sprawl.

back: Close observation
example: especially by authorities.
column5: Mass surveillance by governments raises serious concerns about individual privacy and civil liberties.

back: The system of levying taxes on citizens.
example: Fair and progressive taxation is essential for funding public services and reducing inequality.

back: A change from one state to another.
example: A rapid transition to renewable energy is essential to limit global temperature rise.

back: Openness and clarity in processes or governance.
example: Greater transparency in government spending can help reduce corruption and build public trust.

back: The state of being without paid work.
example: Structural unemployment caused by automation poses a major challenge to governments worldwide.

back: Increasing proportion of people living in cities.
example: Rapid urbanisation in Asia has created mega-cities but also severe infrastructure challenges.

back: Treatment that provides immunity against disease.
example: Mass vaccination programmes have eradicated diseases such as smallpox and controlled polio globally.

back: Done willingly without external compulsion.
example: Voluntary sector organisations play a crucial role in supporting vulnerable members of society.

back: Being exposed to harm or difficulty.
example: Small island nations face extreme vulnerability to the consequences of rising sea levels.

back: Found or distributed over a large area.
example: Widespread access to the internet has transformed communication and access to information globally.

back: All people available for employment.
example: An ageing workforce presents significant challenges for pension systems in developed countries.

back: To produce or provide a result or crop.
example: Improved agricultural techniques have helped farmers yield larger crops in drought-prone regions.

back: To make a problem or situation worse.
example: Climate change is expected to exacerbate existing food security challenges in vulnerable regions.

back: The distribution of resources for a purpose.
example: Effective allocation of public funds is essential for improving national healthcare outcomes.

back: The process of combining parts into a whole.
example: Successful social integration of migrants requires investment in language education and community support.

back: Responsibility for one's actions and decisions.
example: Greater accountability in public institutions is essential for maintaining citizen trust in government.

back: Capable of adjusting to new conditions.
example: Adaptive management strategies allow organisations to respond effectively to rapidly changing environments.

back: To make a problem or situation more serious.
example: Inadequate government response can aggravate the social consequences of an economic recession.

back: Caused or produced by human activity.
example: Scientists agree that anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions are the primary driver of global warming.

back: The absorption of a group into a dominant culture.
example: Forced cultural assimilation of indigenous peoples has been widely condemned by human rights organisations.

back: Severe government spending cuts to reduce debt.
example: Austerity measures imposed after the financial crisis resulted in severe cuts to public services.

back: Use of technology to perform tasks automatically.
example: The automation of manufacturing processes has significantly reduced the need for unskilled labour.

back: Capable of being decomposed by natural organisms.
example: Replacing plastic with biodegradable packaging is a key step towards reducing environmental pollution.

back: A complex system of rules and official processes.
example: Excessive bureaucracy in public institutions can hinder the efficient delivery of essential services.

back: Something that triggers or accelerates a process.
example: The pandemic acted as a catalyst for widespread adoption of remote working practices globally.

back: Active participation in community and political life.
example: Low levels of civic engagement among young people pose a significant threat to democratic governance.

back: Existing together peacefully despite differences.
example: Achieving peaceful coexistence among diverse ethnic communities requires mutual respect and understanding.

back: Relating to mental processes of thought and learning.
example: Early childhood education has a profound impact on long-term cognitive development and academic performance.

back: The quality of forming a united whole.
example: High levels of inequality undermine social cohesion and increase the risk of civil unrest.

back: To treat something as a commercial product.
example: Critics argue that governments should not commodify education by treating it as a market product.

back: Required by law or rules; mandatory.
example: Compulsory education laws have been instrumental in improving literacy rates across the world.

back: To form or develop an idea or plan.
example: It is difficult to conceive of a sustainable future without a radical shift in energy consumption.

back: To combine or strengthen into a unified whole.
example: The merger allowed the two companies to consolidate resources and improve operational efficiency.

back: The presence of harmful pollutants in a substance.
example: Industrial waste has caused widespread contamination of groundwater in the surrounding rural communities.

back: A point of dispute or heated argument.
example: Immigration policy remains a major point of contention in political debates across many countries.

back: To transfer power from central to local authority.
example: Efforts to decentralize governance can empower local communities and improve public service delivery.

back: Done intentionally; to consider carefully.
example: The exclusion of minority voices from policy discussions appears to be a deliberate political strategy.

back: The state of relying heavily on something.
example: Many developing nations struggle to reduce their economic dependency on a single export commodity.

back: A damaging lack of basic necessities.
example: Children raised in areas of severe deprivation are significantly less likely to achieve academic success.

back: Degradation of land into desert-like conditions.
example: Desertification threatens the livelihoods of millions of people living in semi-arid regions worldwide.

back: A process of becoming progressively worse.
example: The deterioration of urban infrastructure poses serious safety risks to residents in many cities.

back: Too large or small relative to something else.
example: Marginalised communities bear a disproportionate burden of the consequences of environmental pollution.

back: Relating to elections or the voting process.
example: Electoral reform is essential to ensure that all citizens are fairly represented in government.

back: Leaving one's country to settle elsewhere.
example: High rates of emigration can deprive developing nations of their most skilled and educated citizens.

back: Based on observation and evidence rather than theory.
example: Sound policy decisions should be based on empirical evidence rather than ideological assumptions.

back: Public declaration of support or approval.
example: A celebrity endorsement can significantly influence public opinion on important social and political issues.

back: The activity of setting up and running businesses.
example: Governments can stimulate economic growth by creating conditions that support entrepreneurship and innovation.

back: A conflict requiring a choice between moral principles.
example: Advances in genetic engineering present society with profound ethical dilemmas that require careful deliberation.

back: The process of making a problem more severe.
example: Rapid population growth leads to the exacerbation of resource shortages in already struggling regions.

back: The act of denying access or membership.
example: Social exclusion of vulnerable groups is a major obstacle to achieving genuine societal equality.

back: Unfair use of someone or something for gain.
example: The exploitation of cheap labour in developing nations by multinational corporations raises serious ethical concerns.

back: Increasing or decreasing at a rapidly accelerating rate.
example: The exponential growth of social media use has transformed the way people consume information globally.

back: Irregular variation or change over time.
example: Sharp fluctuations in global oil prices can destabilise the economies of oil-dependent nations.

back: To create or devise systematically.
example: Governments must carefully formulate policies that balance economic growth with environmental protection.

back: The breaking of something into small
example: isolated parts.
column5: The fragmentation of political parties has made it increasingly difficult to form stable governments.

back: Total monetary value of a country's annual output.
example: Many economists argue that gross domestic product is an inadequate measure of national wellbeing.

back: Dominance of one group over others.
example: The cultural hegemony of Western nations has influenced global media and consumer preferences significantly.

back: Making things uniform or similar throughout.
example: Critics argue that globalisation leads to the cultural homogenization of societies at the expense of diversity.

back: Concerned with improving human welfare and suffering.
example: International humanitarian aid is vital for supporting populations affected by armed conflict and disaster.

back: A system of beliefs underpinning political action.
example: Economic policy is often shaped more by political ideology than by empirical evidence and research.

back: To force something upon others by authority.
example: International bodies may impose sanctions on governments that violate human rights agreements.

back: The state of being imprisoned.
example: High rates of incarceration in some countries raise serious questions about justice and rehabilitation.

back: The beginning or establishment of something.
example: Since its inception
column5: the organisation has made significant progress in alleviating global poverty.

back: Not excluding any group or individual.
example: An inclusive education system ensures that children with disabilities receive equal learning opportunities.

back: Originating naturally in a particular region.
example: The rights of indigenous peoples to their ancestral lands must be protected under international law.

back: Transition to large-scale industrial manufacturing.
example: The industrialisation of developing nations has brought economic growth but also significant environmental damage.

back: Failure to make best use of time or resources.
example: Widespread bureaucratic inefficiency prevents governments from delivering services effectively and equitably.

back: Relating to established organisations or systems.
example: Institutional racism embedded in legal systems continues to disadvantage minority communities worldwide.

back: Mutual reliance between two or more groups.
example: The global pandemic demonstrated the deep interdependence of national economies in the modern world.

back: Using fear or threats to coerce someone.
example: Voter intimidation undermines the democratic process and prevents free and fair elections from occurring.

back: The official authority to administer laws.
example: Cybercrime presents complex challenges because it frequently occurs across multiple legal jurisdictions.

back: To place two things together to highlight contrast.
example: The report juxtaposes the lifestyles of the wealthy elite with those living in extreme poverty.

back: Conforming to law or accepted standards.
example: A legitimate government must be accountable to its citizens and respect fundamental human rights.

back: Poor health from insufficient or unbalanced diet.
example: Widespread malnutrition in conflict zones represents a serious and urgent global humanitarian crisis.

back: A visible sign or expression of something.
example: Homelessness is a stark manifestation of the failure of housing policy in many developed cities.

back: The process of treating a group as peripheral.
example: The marginalisation of ethnic minorities in the labour market perpetuates cycles of poverty and inequality.

back: A system where advancement is based on ability.
example: Critics argue that a genuine meritocracy is impossible while systemic inequality remains unaddressed.

back: Action to reduce the severity of something harmful.
example: Effective mitigation strategies are urgently needed to limit the worst impacts of global climate change.

back: Exclusive control of a market by one entity.
example: Unchecked monopolies reduce competition and ultimately lead to higher prices for consumers.

back: Involving more than two parties or nations.
example: Addressing climate change effectively requires multilateral cooperation among all major emitting nations.

back: Failure to care for or attend to something.
example: Years of political neglect have left many rural communities without adequate healthcare or education.

back: Favouring free markets
example: privatisation
column6: Critics argue that neoliberal economic policies have widened the gap between rich and poor globally.

back: Accepted standards of behaviour in a society.
example: Changing social norms around gender roles have gradually transformed the modern workplace.

back: No longer in use; outdated and superseded.
example: Rapid technological advancement has rendered many traditional manufacturing skills virtually obsolete.

back: Prolonged unjust authority or control over others.
example: Historical oppression of minority groups has created deeply embedded inequalities that persist today.

back: A sudden occurrence of disease or violence.
example: The outbreak of a new viral disease prompted immediate international public health emergency measures.

back: For each person in a given population.
example: GDP per capita is commonly used to compare the average standard of living across different countries.

back: Division into two sharply contrasting groups.
example: Political polarization has made bipartisan cooperation on major national issues increasingly difficult.

back: Transfer of state-owned assets to private ownership.
example: The privatisation of utilities such as water and energy has been widely criticised for reducing accessibility.

back: Rapid increase in the number of something.
example: The proliferation of misinformation on social media poses a serious threat to democratic processes.

back: Nearness in space
example: time
column6: Geographical proximity to economic centres significantly influences a region's development and growth.

back: To formally approve an agreement or law.
example: More countries must ratify the Paris Agreement for global climate commitments to have meaningful impact.

back: Tendency to reoffend after prior conviction.
example: Effective rehabilitation programmes have been proven to reduce recidivism rates among former offenders.

back: Reallocation of resources to achieve greater equality.
example: Progressive taxation enables the redistribution of wealth from the richest to the most disadvantaged.

back: To strengthen or support an existing idea or structure.
example: Media portrayals of crime can inadvertently reinforce negative stereotypes about particular social groups.

back: Ability to recover quickly from difficulties.
example: Building community resilience is essential for helping populations withstand the impacts of climate change.

back: Action taken in response to an injury or attack.
example: Trade retaliation between major economies can trigger a damaging cycle of escalating tariffs.

back: The enforced separation of groups in society.
example: Racial segregation in education systems has long-lasting negative effects on social equality.

back: Relating to both social and economic factors.
example: A child's socioeconomic background remains one of the strongest predictors of educational achievement.

back: Supreme authority and independence of a state.
example: International agreements sometimes conflict with nations' desire to preserve full economic sovereignty.

back: To support financially with government funds.
example: Many governments subsidize renewable energy to make it more competitive with fossil fuels.

back: Likely to be affected by or vulnerable to something.
example: Elderly populations are particularly susceptible to severe illness from respiratory infectious diseases.

back: Relating to a whole system rather than one part.
example: Addressing poverty requires systemic change rather than piecemeal interventions targeting individual symptoms.

back: To express or devise again in a new form.
example: In light of new evidence
column5: governments may need to reformulate their approach to public health policy.

back: A reduction in economic output or activity.
example: The sharp contraction of global trade during the pandemic exposed the fragility of supply chains.

back: A deviation from what is normal or expected.
example: Some economists consider the 2008 financial crisis an aberration rather than a structural failure of markets.

back: To fail to fulfil a duty or responsibility.
example: Governments that cut public services may be accused of abdicating their responsibility to vulnerable citizens.

back: Bitter hostility in speech or manner.
example: The Brexit negotiations were characterised by considerable acrimony between EU and UK representatives.

back: To combine or unite into a single body.
example: Several smaller departments were amalgamated to improve administrative efficiency and reduce operational costs.

back: To make a bad situation better or more tolerable.
example: International aid programmes aim to ameliorate the conditions faced by displaced populations in conflict zones.

back: Something out of place in its historical period.
example: Critics argue that the unelected upper house has become a democratic anachronism in modern society.

back: Lack of equality or equivalence between parts.
example: Information asymmetry between buyers and sellers can lead to market failures and inefficient outcomes.

back: Gradual reduction through sustained pressure or loss.
example: The prolonged conflict became a war of attrition that exhausted the resources of both opposing sides.

back: A division into two branches or parts.
example: Growing inequality has led to a bifurcation of society into two increasingly disconnected economic groups.

back: To find a way around a rule or obstacle.
example: Multinational corporations have been accused of using offshore accounts to circumvent domestic tax obligations.

back: Using force or threats to compel action.
example: The use of coercive measures to suppress political dissent violates fundamental democratic principles.

back: The process of treating something as a marketable commodity.
example: The commodification of higher education has shifted universities from public institutions to commercial enterprises.

back: Satisfied self-satisfaction despite obvious dangers.
example: Political complacency in the face of rising inequality has allowed social divisions to widen significantly.

back: An opinion formed without sufficient evidence.
example: Without empirical data
column5: claims about the economic impact of the policy remain pure conjecture.

back: Dependent on uncertain circumstances or conditions.
example: The success of the reform programme is contingent on sustained political commitment and adequate funding.

back: To confirm or support with evidence.
example: Multiple independent studies corroborate the finding that air pollution significantly increases mortality rates.

back: To reduce or restrict something significantly.
example: Emergency legislation was enacted to curtail civil liberties during the height of the national health crisis.

back: To describe or indicate precisely and clearly.
example: International treaties must clearly delineate the responsibilities of each signatory nation.

back: Economic growth from a larger working-age population.
example: Sub-Saharan Africa has an opportunity to harness its demographic dividend through investment in education.

back: To discourage action through fear or doubt.
example: Heavier penalties for environmental violations may deter corporations from polluting waterways illegally.

back: A sharp division into two contrasting categories.
example: The dichotomy between economic growth and environmental protection is often presented as a false choice.

back: The spread of something across a wide area.
example: The rapid diffusion of digital technology has transformed how information is produced and consumed globally.

back: To deprive someone of rights or privileges.
example: Complex voter registration requirements can disenfranchise low-income and minority communities disproportionately.

back: Essentially different in kind; not comparable.
example: The policy must accommodate the needs of disparate communities with very different economic circumstances.

back: The ability to produce a desired result.
example: Clinical trials must rigorously test the efficacy of new treatments before they are approved for public use.

back: Believing in or advocating equal rights for all.
example: A truly egalitarian society must address both formal legal equality and substantive equality of opportunity.

back: Firmly established and difficult to change.
example: Deeply entrenched gender bias in hiring practices continues to disadvantage women in senior roles.

back: A state of balance between opposing forces.
example: Supply and demand theory holds that markets will naturally tend towards a price equilibrium over time.

back: To completely destroy or eliminate something.
example: The World Health Organisation's goal to eradicate polio globally requires universal vaccination coverage.

back: To extend known data to predict unknown situations.
example: Researchers must be cautious when attempting to extrapolate findings from small samples to entire populations.

back: To invent false information; to manufacture.
example: Journalists who fabricate evidence undermine public trust in the media and damage democratic discourse.

back: The quality of being possible and practical.
example: A comprehensive feasibility study is required before large-scale infrastructure projects are approved.

back: When government spending exceeds its revenue.
example: A growing fiscal deficit forces governments to either raise taxes or cut essential public spending.

back: Innovative and pioneering; introducing new ideas.
example: The groundbreaking research on gene editing has opened new possibilities for treating inherited diseases.

back: Addressing the whole system rather than its parts.
example: A holistic approach to public health must address social

back: Consisting of similar or uniform elements.
example: Increasingly homogeneous urban cultures may erode the rich diversity of traditional local communities.

back: To hinder or obstruct progress or movement.
example: Corrupt bureaucratic practices impede economic development and discourage foreign direct investment.

back: Beginning to happen or develop; in early stages.
example: Early intervention is critical to prevent an incipient economic downturn from becoming a full recession.

back: Done without careful judgment; random and careless.
example: Indiscriminate use of pesticides damages ecosystems and harms species far beyond the intended target.

back: Existing as a permanent essential characteristic.
example: There are inherent tensions between maximising economic growth and protecting the natural environment.

back: To bring about or initiate an action or event.
example: Civil society groups often instigate policy change by mobilising public pressure on government institutions.

back: To lessen the severity or impact of something.
example: Planting urban trees can help mitigate the heat island effect in densely populated cities.

back: To make something continue indefinitely.
example: Educational systems that reflect existing class structures tend to perpetuate rather than reduce social inequality.

back: Dealing with things practically rather than theoretically.
example: A pragmatic approach to migration policy balances humanitarian obligations with realistic social capacity.

back: Uncertain and likely to deteriorate; unstable.
example: The rise of zero-hours contracts has left many workers in a financially precarious and insecure position.

back: Acting in advance to prevent an anticipated event.
example: Some governments argue that preemptive military action is justified when facing an imminent security threat.

back: An indirect consequence of an event or action.
example: Trade wars can have serious economic repercussions for countries far beyond those directly involved.

back: Strict
example: precise
column6: Stringent environmental regulations are necessary to prevent corporations from externalising pollution costs.

back: To weaken or damage something gradually.
example: Widespread corruption undermines public trust in democratic institutions and the rule of law.

back: To adjust or reset in response to new conditions.
example: Governments may need to recalibrate economic policy in response to rapidly changing global market conditions.

back: Adopting cultural traits from another group.
example: The acculturation of migrant communities involves a complex negotiation between heritage and host cultural norms.

back: To make an official judgement or decision.
example: International tribunals exist to adjudicate disputes between nations that cannot be resolved bilaterally.

back: Directly opposed or contradictory to something.
example: Suppressing freedom of speech is antithetical to the foundational principles of liberal democratic governance.

back: Growing or developing rapidly and vigorously.
example: The burgeoning middle class in Southeast Asia is driving unprecedented growth in consumer demand.

back: To come together to form one unified whole.
example: Disparate activist groups began to coalesce around a shared agenda of environmental and social justice.

back: Having knowledge or awareness of something.
example: Policymakers must be fully cognizant of the long-term environmental consequences of industrial development.

back: Having the opposite of the desired effect.
example: Excessively punitive drug policies may be counterproductive
column5: increasing crime rather than reducing substance abuse.

back: Recurring regularly through a repeated sequence.
example: Poverty is often cyclical
column5: passed across generations due to inadequate access to education and opportunity.

back: Political manipulation using populist emotional appeals.
example: The rise of demagoguery in democratic societies poses a serious threat to rational and evidence-based governance.

back: Regularly found and widespread in a particular area.
example: Endemic corruption in public institutions prevents effective delivery of services to citizens in need.

back: Relating to knowledge or the degree of its validation.
example: Epistemic humility requires acknowledging the limits of what we can know when formulating public policy.

back: Requiring immediate action or attention; urgent.
example: The exigent demands of the refugee crisis required an immediate and coordinated international response.

back: Extending or operating beyond territorial boundaries.
example: Some countries apply extraterritorial laws to prosecute companies for bribery committed abroad.

back: Relating to politics influenced by geography.
example: Competition for critical mineral resources is increasingly driving geopolitical tensions between major powers.

back: Diverse in character or composed of different elements.
example: A heterogeneous workforce brings diverse perspectives that can drive greater organisational innovation.

back: Enabling discovery through trial and practical methods.
example: Behavioural economics reveals how cognitive heuristics can lead individuals to make systematically irrational decisions.

back: The process of combining two distinct elements.
example: Cultural hybridization in globalised cities produces new creative forms drawing from multiple traditions.

back: Unchanging over time; impossible to change.
example: Some philosophers hold that moral truths are immutable
column5: while others argue they evolve with society.

back: Impossible to stop or prevent; relentless.
example: The inexorable rise of sea levels poses an existential threat to low-lying coastal communities worldwide.

back: Gradually harmful in a subtle and concealed way.
example: Unconscious bias can have an insidious effect on hiring decisions

back: Too difficult to manage
example: resolve
column6: The Israeli-Palestinian conflict has proved intractable despite decades of international diplomatic efforts.

back: Having many different aspects or dimensions.
example: Addressing climate change requires a multifaceted approach combining technological

back: Just beginning to exist or develop.
example: Investment in a nascent renewable energy sector can help nations transition away from fossil fuel dependence.

back: Relating to or establishing standards of behaviour.
example: Normative assumptions about gender roles can significantly influence educational and workplace policy design.

back: To make something unclear or hard to understand.
example: Politicians sometimes use technical language to obfuscate unpopular decisions from the general public.

back: Seemingly contradictory but possibly true.
example: It is paradoxical that increased access to information has not always led to greater public political engagement.

back: Involving mutual benefit between two entities.
example: The symbiotic relationship between universities and industry drives innovation and economic competitiveness.

back: Lasting only for a short time; temporary.
example: Economic booms driven by commodity exports are often transient and fail to create lasting development.

back: Present and found everywhere simultaneously.
example: Smartphones have become so ubiquitous that digital exclusion now constitutes a serious form of social disadvantage.

back: Relating to dominant power over others.
example: Critics argue that hegemonic Western cultural norms are often imposed on developing nations through global institutions.
